title: Capitalization Rate
equation_latex: Cap Rate = NOI / Property Value
notes: This equation calculates the capitalization rate for real estate. Cap Rate represents the initial yield on a property
column5: NOI is net operating income
column6: and Property Value is the purchase price or market value. Cap rate is used to compare different properties and determine if an investment is attractive based on current income.

title: Net Operating Income
equation_latex: NOI = Effective Gross Income - Operating Expenses
notes: This equation calculates net operating income for real estate. NOI represents the income generated by a property after operating expenses but before debt service and taxes. Effective Gross Income includes rent and other income minus vacancy and collection losses.

title: Effective Gross Income
equation_latex: EGI = Potential Gross Income - Vacancy and Collection Losses
notes: This equation calculates effective gross income for real estate. EGI represents the actual income collected from tenants after accounting for vacancy and collection losses. Potential Gross Income is the income if all units were occupied at full rent.

title: Gross Rent Multiplier
equation_latex: GRM = Property Price / Annual Gross Rent
notes: This equation calculates the gross rent multiplier for real estate. GRM represents how many years of gross rent would be needed to pay for the property. A lower GRM indicates a potentially better investment
column5: though this is a rough metric that doesn't account for expenses.

title: Cash-on-Cash Return
equation_latex: CoC = Annual Cash Flow / Total Cash Invested
notes: This equation calculates cash-on-cash return for real estate. CoC represents the annual return on the actual cash invested
column5: Annual Cash Flow is after all expenses and debt service
column6: and Total Cash Invested includes down payment and closing costs.

title: Capital Recovery Factor
notes: This equation calculates the capital recovery factor for mortgage amortization. CRF represents the mortgage payment as a percentage of the loan amount
column5: r is the periodic interest rate
column6: and n is the number of periods. This factor is used in real estate finance calculations.

title: Vacancy Rate
equation_latex: Vacancy Rate = Vacant Units / Total Units
notes: This equation calculates the vacancy rate for a property. Vacancy Rate represents the percentage of units that are unoccupied
column5: Vacant Units is the count of empty units
column6: and Total Units is the total number of units. Vacancy impacts effective gross income and NOI.

title: Debt Service Coverage Ratio
equation_latex: DSCR = NOI / Annual Debt Service
notes: This equation calculates the debt service coverage ratio. DSCR represents the ability to cover debt obligations from operating income
column5: NOI is net operating income
column6: and Annual Debt Service is the total principal and interest payments. Lenders typically require DSCR > 1.2.

title: Loan-to-Value Ratio
equation_latex: LTV = Loan Amount / Property Value
notes: This equation calculates the loan-to-value ratio. LTV represents the percentage of the property value financed by debt
column5: Loan Amount is the mortgage principal
column6: and Property Value is the purchase price or appraisal. LTV affects interest rates and loan eligibility.

title: Internal Rate of Return (Real Estate)
equation_latex: 0 = sum_{t=1}^n CF_t / (1 + IRR)^t - Initial Investment
notes: This equation calculates IRR for real estate investments. IRR represents the annualized return accounting for all cash flows including operating income
column5: capital expenditures
column6: refinancing
column7: and sale. Real estate IRR typically targets 10-15%.

title: Multiple on Invested Capital
equation_latex: MOIC = Total Distributions / Total Equity Invested
notes: This equation calculates the multiple on invested capital. MOIC represents the total return as a multiple of the initial investment
column5: Total Distributions include all cash flows to investors
column6: and Total Equity Invested is the total capital called. MOIC is commonly reported by private equity firms.

title: Public Market Equivalent
equation_latex: LPME = sum_{t=1}^n CF_t * (1 + r_benchmark)^T-t / Initial Investment
notes: This equation calculates the public market equivalent. LPME represents the multiple achieved relative to a public market benchmark
column5: CF_t are distributions
column6: r_benchmark is the benchmark return
column7: and Initial Investment is the capital deployed. This compares PE performance to public markets.

title: Limited Partner Commitment
equation_latex: LP Commitment = Fund Size * LP Percentage
notes: This equation calculates the commitment from limited partners. LP Commitment represents the capital pledged by LPs to the fund
column5: Fund Size is the total target capital
column6: and LP Percentage is the LP's ownership percentage. LPs commit capital that is drawn down over time.

title: General Partner Carried Interest
equation_latex: GP Carried Interest = 20% * (Total Distributions - Return of Capital)
notes: This equation calculates the general partner carried interest. GP Carried Interest represents the profit share for the GP
column5: which is typically 20% of profits after LPs receive their return of capital. This aligns GP and LP incentives.

title: Catch-Up Provision
equation_latex: LP receives 80% until LP Return of Capital
notes: This equation describes the catch-up provision in PE compensation. After the catch-up
column5: the GP receives a higher percentage (typically 40-50%) until the preferred return is met. This accelerates GP compensation after LPs recover their investment.

title: Preferred Return
equation_latex: LP Preferred Return = Initial Investment * Preferred Rate * Time
notes: This equation calculates the preferred return for LPs. LP Preferred Return represents the return that must be paid to LPs before the GP participates in profits
column5: typically 8% annually. This is a key term in PE partnership agreements.

title: Management Fee
equation_latex: Management Fee = Fund Size * Fee Rate
notes: This equation calculates the annual management fee. Management Fee represents the fee paid to the GP for managing the fund
column5: typically 1.5-2% of committed capital in early years and 0.5-1% of invested capital in later years.

title: Sharpe Ratio for Hedge Funds
equation_latex: Sharpe = (Strategy Return - Risk-Free Rate) / Strategy Volatility
notes: This equation calculates the Sharpe ratio for hedge fund strategies. Sharpe represents risk-adjusted return
column5: Strategy Return is the absolute return
column6: Risk-Free Rate is the benchmark
column7: and Strategy Volatility is the standard deviation of returns. Hedge fund Sharpe ratios often look attractive due to low volatility.

title: Sortino Ratio
equation_latex: Sortino = (R_p - R_f) / sigma_down
notes: This equation calculates the Sortino ratio
column5: a downside risk measure. Sortino represents return per unit of downside risk
column6: R_p is portfolio return
column8: and sigma_down is the standard deviation of negative returns. This is preferred for asymmetric return distributions.

title: Calmar Ratio
equation_latex: Calmar = Annual Return / Maximum Drawdown
notes: This equation calculates the Calmar ratio for hedge funds. Calmar represents return per unit of maximum drawdown
column5: Annual Return is the average annual return
column6: and Maximum Drawdown is the largest peak-to-trough decline. This is particularly relevant for trend-following strategies.

title: Information Ratio
equation_latex: IR = (Portfolio Return - Benchmark Return) / Tracking Error
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio for hedge funds. IR represents active return per unit of tracking error
column5: which measures how consistently a strategy outperforms its benchmark. Higher IR indicates better skill.

title: Maximum Drawdown
equation_latex: MDD = max_{t in [0
notes: Alternative Investments - Hedge Funds
column5: This equation calculates the maximum drawdown for hedge funds. MDD represents the largest peak-to-trough decline
column6: Peak_t is the maximum value before the decline
column7: and Trough_t is the lowest value after. Drawdown risk is crucial for evaluating hedge fund strategies.

title: Sterling Ratio
equation_latex: Sterling = (R_p - R_f) / Average Drawdown
notes: This equation calculates the Sterling ratio. Sterling represents return per unit of average drawdown
column5: R_p is portfolio return
column6: R_f is risk-free rate
column7: and Average Drawdown is the mean of all drawdowns. This complements maximum drawdown with average severity.

title: Burke Ratio
equation_latex: Burke = (R_p - R_f) / sqrt(sum(Drawdown_i^2))
notes: This equation calculates the Burke ratio. Burke represents return per unit of root-mean-square drawdown
column5: which weights larger drawdowns more heavily. This is a more conservative measure of drawdown risk.

title: CTA Strategy Return
equation_latex: R_CTA = sum_{i=1}^n w_i * R_strategy
notes: Alternative Investments - Hedge Funds
column5: This equation calculates the return of a multi-strategy CTA. R_CTA represents the overall CTA return
column6: w_i are the strategy weights
column8: i are the returns of individual strategies. CTA strategies often include trend-following across multiple asset classes.

title: Managed Futures Exposure
equation_latex: Exposure = sum_{i=1}^n w_i * (1 + beta_i) * V_i / Total Vol
notes: This equation calculates the effective exposure of a managed futures portfolio. Exposure represents the systematic market exposure
column5: w_i are positions
column6: beta_i are market betas
column8: and Total Vol is the portfolio volatility. Managed futures can have high effective leverage.

title: Equity Market Neutral Return
equation_latex: R_EMN = alpha + sum beta_j * F_j + epsilon
notes: This equation models the return of an equity market neutral strategy. R_EMN represents the strategy return
column5: alpha is the stock selection skill
column6: beta_j are factor exposures
column8: and epsilon is the idiosyncratic return. Market neutral means zero net market beta.

title: Convertible Bond Delta
equation_latex: Delta_CB = (1 - R) * Delta_option / (1 - R + Delta_option)
notes: This equation approximates the delta of a convertible bond. Delta_CB represents the sensitivity to the underlying stock
column5: R is the recovery rate
column6: and Delta_option is the option delta. Convertible bonds have option-like payoffs.

title: Contingent Convertible (CoCo) Trigger
equation_latex: Trigger = min( CET1 Ratio
notes: Discretionary
column5: Alternative Investments - Structured Products
column6: This equation defines the trigger for contingent convertible bonds. Trigger represents when the CoCo converts to equity or takes a loss
column7: CET1 Ratio is the core equity tier 1 capital ratio
column8: Capital Ratio is total capital ratio

title: Tranche Attachment Point
equation_latex: Attachment = Loss Level where Tranche begins to absorb losses
notes: This equation defines the attachment point of a structured product tranche. Attachment represents the percentage loss level at which the tranche starts absorbing losses. Lower attachment points mean higher risk and higher yield.

title: Tranche Detachment Point
equation_latex: Detachment = Attachment + Tranche Width
notes: This equation defines the detachment point of a structured product tranche. Detachment represents the percentage loss level at which the tranche is completely wiped out. The tranche absorbs losses between attachment and detachment.

title: Expected Tranche Loss
equation_latex: ETL = integral_{Attach}^{Detach} Loss * PDF(Loss) dLoss
notes: This equation calculates the expected loss on a structured product tranche. ETL represents the average loss the tranche will incur
column5: PDF(Loss) is the probability density of portfolio losses
column6: and integration is from attachment to detachment. This is key for pricing and risk management.

title: Subordination Level
equation_latex: Subordination = Attachment Point / Total Portfolio
notes: This equation calculates the subordination level of a tranche. Subordination represents how much of the portfolio is junior to the tranche
column5: Attachment Point is the loss level where the tranche starts absorbing losses
column6: and Total Portfolio is the full notional. Higher subordination means lower risk.

title: Waterfall Distribution
equation_latex: Senior = max(0
notes: Alternative Investments - Structured Products
column5: This equation describes the waterfall distribution in structured products. Senior tranche payments are the remaining cash flow after satisfying junior tranche requirements. Junior tranches absorb losses first
column6: providing credit enhancement to seniors.

title: Collateral Coverage
equation_latex: Coverage = Collateral Value / Senior Tranche Notional
notes: This equation calculates the collateral coverage for a structured product. Coverage represents how well the collateral backs the senior tranche
column5: Collateral Value is the mark-to-market value of assets
column6: and Senior Tranche Notional is the senior tranche size. Coverage below 100% increases senior risk.
